Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Integrating microtome sectioning with isotopic tracing to study biotransformation in synthetic Escherichia coli biofilms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1700881/1700935
Tang/Ren

Biofilms are created by colonies of bacteria with polymeric substances produced by the cells. With a high-level of tolerance to a variety of stresses, biofilms cause serious problems in both industrial (biofouling and corrosion) and healthcare (persistent infections) settings. On the other hand, biofilms of environmentally friendly bacteria have promising applications in bioremediation and biofuel production. This project will develop a new method for investigating nutrient transport and enzyme activity of using Escherichia coli as a model organism.

The PIs have extensive research experience in E. coli metabolic analysis and biofilm physiology. This team will develop and test a new biofilm study method by integrating several interdisciplinary approaches: 1) culture synthetic biofilms with controlled morphology to reduce spatial variation in gene expression and enzymatic functions; 2) use microtome sectioning to obtain thin slides of biofilm samples with cells in similar metabolic/nutrient transport status; and, 3) apply a stable isotopic labeling method (i.e., 13C-pulse) to trace nutrient mass transfer within biofilm layers as well as intracellular free metabolite conversions along functional pathways. The transient labeling in cascade metabolites can reveal the speed of substrate diffusion through biofilm layers as well as the rate of biotransformation into downstream intracellular metabolites. It can also determine these active biotransformation pathways important for biofilm survival and growth. Ultimately, the outcome of this exploratory project will be a new method for studying biofilm physiology (i.e., intracellular biotransformation) of diverse environmental microbes. This biofilm study technology will reveal regulatory mechanisms of biofilm growth and persistence under environmental stresses (e.g., antibiotic conditions); and it will improve our understandings of diverse biofilm systems from environmental microbes to pathogens. Specifically, Escherichia coli will be used as a model bacterium in this project with complementary studies outlined in the following Tasks: 1. Create synthetic biofilms with rigorously controlled morphology to reduce structural heterogeneity. 2. Optimize microtome technology to quench and sample free metabolites from different layers of biofilm cells, which can be analyzed via liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. 3. Validate this new method by conducting 13C-pulse experiments with microtome sectioning and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis of cascade metabolites to determine glucose transfer and biotransformation rates across different layers of E. coli biofilm cells. This project will result in a new approach to section biofilms to detect metabolite biotransformation and probe the pathway function with desired spatial resolutions. The interdisciplinary nature of this work and the development of new tools outlined herein will build the foundation for advanced research and innovation to address many grand challenges associated with microbial biofilms at molecular level. It will provide new insights into nutrient transport and intracellular enzyme conversions within the biofilm matrix; and help reveal regulatory mechanisms and essential pathways for biofilm survival under diverse environmental conditions. Such insights can help researchers design more effective way to control biofilm physiologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Bacterial biofilms are multicellular structures embedded in a matrix of extracellular polymeric substance produced by the attached cells. Despite the well-recognized significance of biofilms, a mechanistic understanding of nutrient transport and nutrient biotransformation during biofilm formation is still missing. To bridge this knowledge gap, the EAGER project is proposed to develop new methods for investigating nutrient transport and intracellular enzyme activities of biotransformation across different layers of bacterial biofilms using Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa as model organisms.

 

In the past year, the two labs (Tang and Ren) have developed new protocols to accurately measure the intracellular biotransformation of cascade metabolites in central pathways of biofilm cells. Moreover, the comparison of metabolite transformation rates between biofilm and planktonic cells also provides new insights into nutrient transport from medium through biofilm matrix and cell metabolic responses to diffusional limitations. Our new biofilm analysis protocol integrates several interdisciplinary approaches: 1) culture synthetic biofilms with controlled morphology to reduce spatial variation in gene expression and enzymatic functions; 2) apply a stable isotopic labeling method (i.e., 13C-pulse) to trace nutrient mass transfer within biofilm layers as well as intracellular free metabolite conversions along functional pathways; 3) develop fast-quenching and sampling methods for biofilm metabolite analysis; 4) build LC-MS procedures and metabolic models to reveal the speed of substrate diffusion through biofilm layers as well as the rate of biotransformation into downstream intracellular metabolites.

 

In a case study, we have used 13C- tracing, microscopy image, and transcription analysis to reveal metabolic features in biofilm of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1. We have three key findings. First, we found that the biofilm cell showed similar fluxome topology to planktonic cells cultured from shake flasks (biofilm cell had slightly lower respirations rates). Specifically, glucose catabolism in the PAO1 biofilm operated via two major routes: an Entner-Doudoroff-Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas loop and the TCA cycle. Second, the difference between PAO1 and its biofilm overproducing mutant (both grew in biofilm reactors) was not observable from 13C-labeling of results. Third, dynamic labeling of matured biofilm cells indicated that the majority of biofilm cells (>90%) was metabolic active but their glucose utilization rate was much slower than planktonic cells (turnover time of intracellular glucose-6-P: ~3hrs vs. 5 minutes), possibly due to mass transfer limitations and repressed glycolytic genes (such as pgi and fbp). In summary, this study suggests those actively-dividing biofilm cells may operate identical metabolisms to their planktonic counterparts (Note: a research paper is in preparation to report these results). 

 

Broader Impact: This project partially supports one female PhD student (Ni Wan). Ni has successfully defended her PhD thesis (Application of metabolic modeling and machine learning for investigating microbial systems) and starts to work as a scientist in Monsanto. Meanwhile, the Tang Lab continues to promote STEM education with a special focus on students from under-represented groups and low income families. Last year, the Tang Lab invited Kam'Ron Battle (African American student) from Hazelwood East High School in North St. Louis County to work on computer modeling. He is now a college student in the engineering school of Missouri University of Science and Technology.

 

After this EAGER project, the team aims to quantitatively characterize the activities of bioconversion pathways in environmentally important biofilm microorganisms (such as), which will be pursued through a regular NSF proposal.
